conversation.content: What the hell are you doing here, Marcus? Get off this corner right now before I, uh, before I have to sweep around whatever mess you're making.
[defensive] Just standing here talking to friends, Uncle Ray. [coughs] Last I checked that wasn't illegal, and you're not a cop anyway, you just clean the streets.
[angry] Don't play dumb with me, I saw the handoff from half a block away. [pause] Your mother thinks you're at community college right now, studying for your finals or whatever.
[bitter] Yeah well, community college doesn't pay for Mom's medication, does it? [quietly] You know how much her prescriptions cost every month? Three hundred dollars we don't have.

[frustrated] So this is your solution? Standing on corners like some, some stereotype? [sighs] Twenty years I've been cleaning these streets, watching kids like you throw their lives away for quick cash.
[impatient] Kids like me? [laughs] You mean kids trying to keep their families from getting evicted? Sorry we can't all be satisfied with minimum wage and a city pension, Uncle.
At least I can look your grandmother in the eye at Sunday dinner without lying about where my money comes from, you understand what I'm saying?
[curt] Grandma's dead, remember? [pause] Has been for two years, but you'd know that if you actually came around instead of just preaching at us when it's convenient.
[shaky voice] I meant... look, that's not the point here. The point is you're better than this, Marcus. [exhales] Your dad would be rolling in his grave seeing you out here like this.
[angry] Don't you dare bring up my father! [voice breaking] He worked himself to death in that warehouse for pennies while people like his bosses got rich off his labor.
[firmly] He worked honest though, kept his dignity intact. [sighs] That means something, or at least it used to mean something to this family before everything went to hell.
[bitterly] Dignity doesn't keep the lights on, Uncle Ray. [pause] But hey, you keep pushing that broom and telling yourself you're morally superior while we lose the apartment next month.
[desperate] Then come work with me! The city's hiring, I can get you in, benefits and everything. It's not glamorous but it's steady, it's real work, legitimate work that won't land you in prison.
[sarcastically] Forty hours a week for what you make? [laughs bitterly] I make that in two days out here, sometimes three if it's slow, and nobody's breathing down my neck about attendance.
You make that until you're dead or locked up, which at this rate will be what, six months? A year if you're lucky?
[quietly] Maybe. [pause] But Mom gets her medicine this month, and that's all I'm thinking about right now, not some hypothetical future where everything magically works out.
[exhausted] I've got two hundred in my truck, take it and get off this corner. [sighs] Tell your boys you're done for the day, family emergency or something, I don't care what.
[surprised] I don't need your money, Uncle. [defensive] I'm not some charity case you can just throw cash at to make yourself feel better about abandoning us.
Take the damn money!
[resigned] Fine. [long pause] But this doesn't change anything, you know that right? Tomorrow I'll be right back here because your two hundred dollars lasts exactly five days in our world.

scenario: A street sweeper operator encounters their nephew selling drugs on the corner they're about to clean, forcing a confrontation about the path he's chosen.
